III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Mental health service recommendations for Youth A provided to
the facility during a visit to the hospital on 07/14/2024 were not
followed.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 09/04/2024
and provided no further information.
Youth A was interviewed on 07/30/2024 during an unannounced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. He recalled several instances of
going to the hospital to receive outside medical treatment within
the past month. Youth A stated he believed Staff 1 and Staff 2
had taken him to the hospital on the date in question. This need
for medical attention was to address previous self-inflicted wounds
on Youth A’s forearm that he picked at and opened. Youth A
believed the hospital had recommended he stay and be admitted
for longer term care. Youth A believed that is what he needed
because he had felt suicidal, but could not specify if that was what
was occurring on 07/14/2024. Youth A could not recall exactly
why he was taken from the hospital at that time. He did recall
coming back to the facility and then going back to the hospital a
few hours later, when he was released back to the facility again.
Nurse 1 was interviewed over the phone on 09/04/2024. Nurse 1
was not employed or affiliated with the facility, she stated she
worked at the hospital that provided care for Youth A on
07/14/2024. She stated she did not meet Youth A during this visit
but was able to provide additional information regarding his visit
through hospital documentation. Nurse 1 reported Youth A was
initially triaged for care for his arm and once that was completed,
he spoke with social work staff at the hospital. She was not able
to identify who that was from internal documentation. When he
first arrived at the hospital, Youth A was asked if he felt suicidal,
2

and he stated “somewhat” but that he did not have any plans.
She stated that notes in the hospital’s medical documentation
system stated Youth A was to then complete a psychiatric
assessment, but also other notes stated that was not the case and
he would be recommended for discharge. Nurse 1 stated Youth A
was brought back into the hospital a few hours later after being
called and requested to do so by hospital staff and then received
an assessment to determine the need for inpatient psychiatric
care. Nurse 1 stated this assessment recommended continued
outpatient services and Youth A was then discharged.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone on 09/05/2024. He
recalled being with Youth A at the hospital on the afternoon in
question. Staff 1 stated he was told by the front desk that Youth A
was ready for discharge after his arm was treated and Youth A
spoke with a hospital social worker. He recalled discussion of a
psychiatric evaluation, but confirmed with nursing staff at the front
desk that was not going to occur at this time and Youth A would
be discharged. Staff 1 could not recall Youth A saying anything
that gave him concern for his mental well being. Staff 1 could not
recall any of the nursing staff names. He stated he was trained on
these “hospital runs” to ensure leaving with documentation of the
youth’s medical treatment to bring back to the facility. Staff 1
recalled taking documentation back to the facility, but he could not
recall any specifics on what that documentation contained.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone on 09/10/2024. Staff 2
recalled taking Youth A to the hospital with Staff 1 on the date in
question. Staff 2 believed the original reason for the hospital trip
was to ensure that Youth A’s arm was able to receive treatment
for self-induced injuries to his forearm. She recalled discussions
about Youth A receiving a mental health evaluation after his arm
was treated but did not believe she ever heard Youth A say
anything that was of concern regarding self harm or suicidal
ideations on that day. Staff 2 recalled Youth A was moved rooms
and hospital staff stated numerous times this occurred because
they were getting him ready to be discharged. Staff 2 believed it
was a nurse at the front desk that eventually instructed them to
leave and Youth A was discharged.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 09/05/2024. Staff 3
recalled taking Youth A back to the hospital later in the evening on
the date in question. He was told to do so by a supervisor. Staff 3
stated this trip to the hospital was for the purpose of having Youth
A participate in a psychiatric evaluation performed by hospital
staff. Staff 3 recalled Youth A participated in the evaluation, and it
3

was recommended he be discharged and continue to receive
outpatient services at the facility. Staff 3 recalled Youth A did not
disclose during the evaluation that he ever intended to harm
himself further than he had on his arm prior and felt safe at the
facility. Staff 3 stated the hospital then discharged Youth A and
they returned to the facility without issue.
Youth A’s DHHS Foster Care Worker was interviewed over the
phone on 09/05/2024. She recalled the date in question where
Youth A had been taken to the hospital to receive treatment for
self induced wounds to his arm, and then return for psychiatric
evaluation. DHHS Foster Care Worker stated Youth A had been
transported to the hospital frequently prior to and after that
07/14/2024 for other incidents of attempted self harm and
expressions of desire for further self harm. She stated she had
not had any concern about the facility’s response to Youth A’s
needs at that point. DHHS Foster Care Worker recalled the date
in question because it occurred on a Sunday, and she received
documentation the next day and had a voicemail left for her the
previous day after staff arrived at the hospital with Youth A.
DHHS Foster Care Worker recalled Youth A being admitted to the
hospital on a separate day later in the week and that was the first
time since his placement at the facility that he had been screened
through a psychiatric assessment at the hospital and
recommended for inpatient treatment.
Documentation reviewed:
• Incident Report documentation from the facility dated
07/14/2024. In this documentation it was described that
Youth A was transported to the hospital to receive medical
treatment because he had removed bandages to his arm,
causing previous wounds to reopen. It stated that staff and
Youth A left for the hospital at 11:29 am and returned to the
facility at 4:39 pm.
• Discharge Instruction documentation from Children’s
Hospital of Michigan for Youth A. This was dated
07/14/2024 and 07/15/2024 and contained information
about the first visit and medical care provided to Youth A’s
arm, as well as the second visit on the same day and
evaluation completed with a recommendation of continued
outpatient services.
• Facility policy titled “Emergency Medical Services” was
provided and reviewed. It stated that “All requested
documentation on the emergency medical situation should
be completed and forwarded to the Center Director”
referencing internal documentation for the facility.
4

Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed. There was not evidence
found that showed that Youth A did not receive proper and timely
medical care.
Technical Assistance provided:
• The facility was advised to ensure staff are instructed to not
leave a hospital setting without documentation of a
discharge, and that they read the documentation provided
to them prior to leaving to reduce the chance of any
confusion on medical recommendations.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
